He was interrupted by their questions and managed to tell them the most important things he knew about the last year of Raskolnikov’s life. He ended with a detailed account of his illness. However, he left out many things that were better not mentioned, including the incident at the police station and what happened after. They listened eagerly to his story, and when he thought he was done and satisfied them, he realized they felt he had barely started.

“Tell me, tell me! What do you think…? Excuse me, I still don’t know your name!” Pulcheria Alexandrovna quickly added.

“Dmitri Prokofitch.”

“I would really like to know, Dmitri Prokofitch… how he sees things now, that is, what are his likes and dislikes? Is he always so irritable? Please tell me if you can, what are his hopes and dreams? What influences him now? In short, I would like to…”

“Ah, mother, how can he answer all that at once?” Dounia commented.

“Good heavens, I didn’t expect him to be like this at all, Dmitri Prokofitch!”

“Of course,” Razumihin replied. “I don’t have a mother, but my uncle comes every year and he can hardly recognize me, even in looks, though he is smart. Three years apart means a lot. What can I tell you? I have known Rodion for a year and a half; he is gloomy, sad, proud, and haughty.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin describes Raskolnikov's character as morose, gloomy, proud, and haughty, while Pulcheria Alexandrovna expresses her eagerness to understand her son's current state.
